text:

THIS OPINION
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Linda Lee
      Henderson Powell, Petitioner,
				v.
				James Kevin
      Powell, Respondent.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF
  APPEALS

Appeal From McCormick County
Â C. David Sawyer, Jr., Family Court Judge
Memorandum Opinion No. 2008-MO-038
Heard June 11, 2008 â€“ Filed September 8,
  2008 
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Timothy
  E. Madden and Reid T. Sherard, both of Nelson Mullins Riley & Scarborough, of
  Greenville, for Petitioner.
				Thomas
  M. Neal, III, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	


PER CURIAM:Â  We granted a writ of certiorari to review
  the Court of Appealsâ€™ opinion in Powell v. Powell, Op. No 2005-UP-595,
  S.C. Ct. App. filed Nov. 21 2005).Â  Â We reverse.Â  
FACTS
This is a divorce
  action in which Wife filed a complaint seeking a divorce on grounds of
  adultery.Â  After a three day trial, the family court granted Wife a divorce
  based on Husbandâ€™s adultery.Â  The family court awarded Wife $4,000 per month in
  alimony and apportioned the marital property, sixty-eight percent to Wife and
  thirty-two percent to Husband.Â  Additionally, the family court ordered Husband
  to maintain Wifeâ€™s medical insurance, maintain a life insurance policy naming
  Wife as an irrevocable beneficiary to secure his alimony obligation, pay Wife
  $30,000 in attorneyâ€™s fees, and pay $9,000 for Wifeâ€™s expert witness.Â Â Â  
The Court of
  Appeals affirmed in part, and reversed in part.Â  Taking its own view of the
  preponderance of the evidence, the Court of Appeals found the family court
  erred in granting Wife a divorce on the ground of Husbandâ€™s adultery. Â It held
  Husband had not condoned Wifeâ€™s adultery, and found Husband had established the
  defense of recrimination to Wifeâ€™s request for a divorce based on adultery.Â  The
  Court of Appeals modified the decree to grant the partiesâ€™ divorce on the
  ground of one yearâ€™s continuous separation.Â  
Since it found Wife
  had not proved Husband condoned her adultery, the Court of Appeals held she was
  barred from receiving alimony.Â  Accordingly, the family courtâ€™s award of
  alimony, its order requiring Husband to maintain Wifeâ€™s health insurance
  coverage, and its order requiring Husband to maintain life insurance to secure
  the alimony, were reversed.Â  The award of attorneyâ€™s fees and costs to Wife was
  remanded to the family court.Â  We granted certiorari.
ISSUE[1]
Did the Court of Appeals err in reversing the family
  courtâ€™s holding that Husband condoned Wifeâ€™s adultery?

DISCUSSION
Wife
  contends the Court of Appeals erred in reversing the family courtâ€™s holding
  that Husband had condoned her adultery, claiming it failed to give the family
  courtâ€™s finding due deference, particularly with reference to matters of
  credibility.Â Â  We agree.
In appeals from the
  family court, the appellate court has the authority to correct errors of law
  and to find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the
  evidence.Â  Wooten v. Wooten, 364 S.C. 532, 540, 615 S.E.2d 98, 102
  (2005); Miller v. Miller, 299 S.C. 307, 311, 384 S.E.2d 715, 717
  (1989).Â  However, this broad scope of review does not require this court to
  disregard the family courtâ€™s findings.Â  Appellate courts should be mindful that
  the family court, who saw and heard the witnesses, sits in a better position to
  evaluate credibility and assign comparative weight to the testimony.Â  Because
  the appellate court lacks the opportunity for direct observation of the
  witnesses, it should accord great deference to trial court findings where
  matters of credibility are involved.Â  Marquez v. Caudill, 376 S.C. 229,
  656 S.E.2d 737 (2008); Dodge v. Dodge, 332 S.C. 401, 505 S.E.2d 344
  (Ct.App.1998).Â  â€œ[W]here there is disputed evidence, the appellate court may adhere
  to the findings of the family court. . . .Â  Because the family court is in a
  superior position to judge the witnessesâ€™ demeanor and veracity, its findings should
  be given broad discretion. . . . Furthermore, the appellate court â€˜should be reluctant to substitute its own evaluation of the evidence . . . for that
  of the [family] court.â€™â€Â  Scott v. Scott, 354 S.C. 118, 124, 579 S.E.2d
  620, 623 (2003).Â  (Emphasis supplied; internal citation omitted).Â  
Condonation is the
  forgiveness, either express or implied, of a prior matrimonial offense by one
  spouse for a breach of marital duty by the other on the condition that it not
  be repeated.Â  It is primarily a state of mind, the existence of which may
  appear either from the language used, from conduct, or both.Â  Wilson v. Wilson, 274 S.C. 236, 262 S.E.2d 732 (1980); McLaughlin v. McLaughlin,
  244 S.C. 265, 136 S.E.2d 537 (1964).Â  Condonation may be presumed from
  cohabitation; and a lapse of time, or continuance of marital cohabitation with
  knowledge of the offense, raises a presumption of condonation.Â  Although this
  presumption may be rebutted by evidence of the accompanying circumstances, the
  burden of rebutting it is on the plaintiff.Â  McLaughlin.Â  
It is undisputed
  here that both parties engaged in adulterous relationships.Â  The sole issue is
  whether Husband condoned Wifeâ€™s adultery, and if not, whether he proved the
  defense of recrimination, as a bar to Wifeâ€™s receipt of alimony.Â  The family
  court held as follows:

	Husband
  claims Wife committed adultery with Ray Wright in about 1997.Â  At trial,
  Husband contended he first learned of Wifeâ€™s adultery at the deposition of Wife
  taken in this case on September 5, 2001.Â  However, in his original, pro se
  Answer and Counterclaim, Husband alleged Wife committed adultery with Mr.
  Wright.Â  In this affidavit he filed at the temporary hearing, Husband swore
  Wife â€œbecame involved in an adulterous affair with Ray Wright.â€Â  At his own
  deposition, prior to the deposition of Wife, Husband maintained he
  believed Wife committed adultery with Mr. Wright based on a telephone
  conversation he had with Mrs. Wright.Â  Wife credibly testified at trial that
  Husband confronted her about Mr. Wright in about 1997.Â  It was clear to Wife
  that Husband believed she had committed adultery with Mr. Wright and Husband
  told Wife to â€œtake care of it.â€Â  Therefore, even if Husband met his burden of
  proof and appropriately corroborates Wifeâ€™s adultery, Wife provided through clear
  and convincing evidence that any adultery committed by her was condoned and
  forgiven by Husband prior to the separation of the parties and prior to the
  commencement of Husbandâ€™s adulterous relationship with Ms. Marlett.Â  

The Court of
  Appeals reversed the finding of condonation, finding Husbandâ€™s allegations that
  he believed Wife had engaged in an adulterous affair were not tantamount to
  â€œfull knowledgeâ€ of the affair.[2] Â The Court of Appeals found that, prior to Wifeâ€™s deposition, Husband had only
  a suspicion that Wife engaged in an adulterous affair.Â Â  
Although we are
  mindful that an appellate court may take its own view of the preponderance of
  the evidence, under the limited factual circumstances presented, we find the
  Court of Appeals erred in substituting its own view of the evidence.Â  Husband
  testified that although he believed Wife had had an affair, this belief was not
  confirmed until the time of Wifeâ€™s deposition.Â  The family court held, â€œWife
  credibly testified at trial that Husband confronted her about Mr. Wright in
  about 1997.Â  It was clear to Wife that Husband believed she had committed
  adultery with Mr. Wright and Husband told Wife to â€œtake care of it.â€ Â Â The
  family court, which heard and saw the witnesses, was in the better position to
  assess the credibility of the parties and specifically found Wifeâ€™s testimony
  credible.Â  Given these facts, we find the Court of Appeals erred in
  substituting its own view of the evidence on the issue of witness credibility.Â 
  Accordingly, we reverse the Court of Appealsâ€™ holding, and reinstate the order
  of the family court.Â  
REVERSED.Â  
TOAL, C.J.,
  MOORE, WALLER, PLEICONES, JJ., and Acting Justice Peter L. Fuge, concur.

[1]Â  We need address only Wifeâ€™s first issue.
[2]Â  In holding Husband did not condone Wifeâ€™s
  conduct because he did not have â€œfull knowledgeâ€ of the affair, the Court of Appeals
  employed a standard of â€œknowledgeâ€ which is not consistent with our established
  law of condonation.Â  Accordingly, the Court of Appealsâ€™ holding based on this
  application of a heightened standard is reversed.

PER CURIAM: Â In
  this post-conviction relief (PCR) matter, petitioner seeks a writ of certiorari
  to review the portion of the PCR judgeâ€™s order finding he is entitled to a
  belated review of his direct appeal issues.
Because
  there is sufficient evidence to support the PCR judgeâ€™s ruling that petitioner
  did not knowingly and intelligently waive his right to a direct appeal, we
  grant the petition for a writ of certiorari and proceed with a review of the
  direct appeal issue pursuant to Davis v. State, 288 S.C. 290, 342 S.E.2d
  60 (1986).
Counsel
  for petitioner has filed a brief pursuant to Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738, 87 S.Ct. 1396, 18 L.Ed.2d 493 (1967) and a petition to be relieved as counsel.Â 
  Petitioner has not filed a pro se response.Â  After a thorough
  review of the record pursuant to Anders, we dismiss the appeal and grant
  the petition to be relieved as counsel.
DISMISSED.
TOAL,
  C.J., WALLER, PLEICONES, BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.
